DIV1.P: THE Religious-Rebell, OR THE Pilgrim-Prince. A TRAGAEDY.

LIST.ITEM: Henry the Fourth Emperour of Germany.

Saxon Nobles
Magnus
Rodolphus
Frederick
Otho.

Nobles of Italie.
Prudentio
Honorio
Junio.

Women.
Sophrona, The Empresse.
Aurelia, Her Daughter.
Sylvia, Her Maid of Honour.
Madam Matilda, a great Court Lady:
Ladies.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. 1 Scen. 1.

SP.SPEAKER: Hil.
SP.L: MAss! thou hast got a luckie hand Brazutus,
The Septicollis now of Rome is levell'd,
My way made even to St. Peters chair,
The Popedome mine!

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: God bless your Holiness!
Never had men quicker dispatch to Heaven,
(I Judge Sir) that those seven your predecessors,
Thanks to my luckey starres, and pills! (then which
There can be nothing more Infallible)
(Your Holiness excepted)

SP.SPEAKER: Hil.
SP.L: Here's my hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: Your Toe, good Sir, your Toe's too great a honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Hil.
SP.L: Murder as many as thou canst, Brazutus,
(Husband it likewise to thy best advantage,
I know mens Deaths must be thy Livelyhood)
You freely have my Dispensation for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: All thanks, Sir,
My study shall be to deserve it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hil.
SP.L: Harke.
They come, I must retire.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Cardinal Victor, with a Mitre, other Cardinals, Monks Fryers, with a mixt company.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.L: God save the Pope!

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: Peter th' Apostle chooseth Hildebrand!

SP.SPEAKER: Jo.
SP.L: Master! the Kettle-drumms past by just now.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: Peace foole, those were religious men, call'd Fryers.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Men! shave they for the scabb? or were half poyson'd?
Pox on the bungler! could his feeble dosse,
But fetch the hair off?

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: No Jests now, Jocoso.
Hasten home, I am with you straight; but first
Will fetch my Patent, to prepare for travel:
I cannot think it safe, abiding here,
So near the Pope, should once his Magick prompt
Him to beleive, some liberal bribes might tempt
Me to ridd him hence (by one slight or other)
(To make all sure) he'd send me packing first.
For all his fair pretenses I confess,
I dare not too much trust his Holyness.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. 1. Scen. 2.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Honorio, Prudentio, to them Junio:

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: How can the Emperour take this Prudentio:

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: Pride and Ambition ruines all the world.
Truth, Sir, I fear 'twill breed bad bloud, if not
Timely made up; He's a Prince wise and valiant,
And wont be baulk'd thus of his ancient right.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: Hildebrand reckons all the Roman Empire,
May I not say the the whole fourth Monarchie?
For Peter's Patrimony, falling now,
To him, whereof he will be sole, supream;
Making the Scepter level to his Mitre.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: Must none arrive to heaven without his leave,
Nor yet possess the earth in any quiet?
Would he be Metropolitane of both?
I must confess, to men in Sacred Orders,
We owe all love, awful respect and honour;
Yet there are two extreams do ill become
Their cloth Honorio, Pride and Poverty:
I'de neither have them swell, nor starve to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: Here comes mad Junio.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: God save you, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: Yours Prudentio, Honorio I am yours!

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: Junio, sweet Junio! prethee lad, what news?

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: Faith, that which makes me laugh, Sir, The new Pope
(Talking against Massing-Preists Wives already:)
Hath wrought the prettiest different effect:
Some storme, and some are glad on't: The one swears
(Should he nere use bead more) he'l never quit
His pretty Bety for an Ave Marie.
h' other complains, Nets Lectures spoil his Sermons.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: Mad Junio still.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: Troth, I am serious, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: Prethee speak

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: I am, and can tell you further,
Th' Arch-bishops Grace of Mentz, the other day,
Pressing this Order, from his Holiness,
Narrowly scap'd his life.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: What project's this?
I warrant you Prudentio, Some cunning
Citizen Miser (to preserve his purse)
(Fearing least his Impropriated Preist
Might Marry, and so leave a parish charge)
Hath put it in his head.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: With this perswasion.
Most Benefic'd men dying Batchelours,
Would make him Heir, and so enrich his See.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: I had almost forgot to tell you too:
Those who contrive the thriftiest way to live,
Think Wives, will be as cheap as Concubines.
Cardinal Cremensis the other day,
(Arguing fiercely 'ganst Priests-Matrimonie)
Was catcht that night bedding a common strumpet.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: I fear this design will but promote
Lusts more, and secret Murders to conceal 'um.
Restraint oft creates those unruly passions,
Which Freedom, slights.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: But Gentlemen! before
We part let's clash one pint of Wine together,
I'le give you that shall be most excellent.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: All thanks kind Junio. Ho. We'll accept your proffer.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: With all my heart; now I could hugg you dearly.
Let times go how they will, the Grape-juyce merits
My praises still, for that preserves my spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: Poetical!

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: Whether or no, you know it:
The very thoughts of Sack will make a Poet.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: Ha. ha. ha.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. 1. Scen. 3.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Emperour, Henry, Conrade, Attendants. to them Otho.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: It can't be born! Princes are things too holy
For Popes to oole: Hath kind fate blest me with
Such conquest o're the Saxons, and will this
Religious Rebel, now spoyl all at home?
To make a Pope without me, is all one
As to unmake me.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.L: Sir, I thought that past
The reach of mortals, dare they snarch that Crown off,
Which none, but a Divine hand setled on you?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: They had as good seek to unravel Heaven,
And fetch the Diety thence.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: My Sons talk,
As if descended, from Imperial Loines;
But what wont human Impudence attempt,
Spurr'd with ambition?
What meanes this haste?

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: Hildebrand's Nuntio, is arriv'd, Sir, And—

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: And what, Sends for my Scepter doth he not?
May I nere more ask pardon of my sins!
If this steel doth not make him cry me mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: And so he doth, Sir, may it please your Highness!

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: He shall know that there was a Caesar long
Before St. Peter, or his Successor
Were ever thought on. Otho. May it please your Highness!

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: The Election of the Pope from Constantine
Descended to Me, Otho, Reckon that.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: 'Tis now Seven Hundred years agon, and upwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Nor shall this ome-Usurper stand a day,
Can I but once reach Italie.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: Please you —
Sir, Hear me, Hildebrand is sorry.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: For that he cannot, Sir, play Prester John.
Be Prince and Prelate too.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp,
SP.L: Grant he were so,
Could it be thought these twins of government,
Might ever wrangle in the self-same breast
For the Supremacy; It would be found,
(I lay my life on't) that St. Peters Chair
Must owe it self upheld by Caesars Throne.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: Sir,—

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: No Bull like the roaring Cannon, No
Anathama like a good Sword and Pistol.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: I see I am still disturb'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Go on, Otho.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: For ought we hear, Sir, Hildibrand is sorry,
The lawless rout of common people should
Cry him up Pope: which Title he protests
He ne're will own, Sir, without your Election.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: I hate this flattering.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: It takes too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: Till when he hath refus'd Inauguration.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Now thou saist somewhat.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: For this very purpose,
Comes th'Embassie.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: This is some satisfaction.
Receive 'um, we will give 'um some Audience.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Were it not fit Hildebrand should have made
Most Royal, Sir, a Personal submission?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Proxy humilitie seems but presumption.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: I see Youth's rash and inconsiderate,
It was the giddie factious multitude,
Not he (my Boyes) intruded on my right.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Con. Sir, we submit.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Haste then without delay,
To grace the Entertainment.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: We obey.

DIV3.HEAD: Act 1. Scen. 4.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Rodolphus, Magnus, Frederick in Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.L: And is the Emperours promise come to this?
Is this his Liberty?

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: A Princes word
I took to be, as true as Heaven it self.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: For this I'le n'ere believe a Conquest more,
But what shall meet me over eares in bloud.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: 'Twas not we feared death as to be thought
Foolishly lavish of our lives: to fight
For that liberty, we might have with peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: Would we had dyed before we yeilded.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.L: Hark! They sing and dring within.

L.HI: Here's to that Noble Soul;
Drowns his sins in a Bowl;
And cares not a fig for the Pope.
Here's to him a full Glasss,
That counts him an Asse,
Who will stinch at the sight of the Rope.

SP.SPEAKER: All within.
SP.L: Ho Boyes!

SP.SPEAKER: First.
SP.L: A merry life and a short.
About with it.
Where lyes the fault?
Roger 'tis your liquor.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: O plague, I drank the very last but one,
Ralph wants it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.L: O Brave Roarers! They know no other prayers.
These are their Mattins, and their Evening Songs.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: Is there such mirth in death?

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: Or are they rather
Glad that the friendly Halter shortly will
Free them from Goal, which I count worse then death.
VVhat man that hath that Noble thing call'd Soul
But hates confinement? This whole world would be
To narrow for him, were he alwaies tied to'r.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.L: But these poor souls are hardned in their Irons.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: I was in hopes that breach like to have bin
Betwixt the Emperour and the Pope of late,
Would have made our way out

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.L: But that's all dash't.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: Could not our old friend (Otho having got
Into such favour) do us here a kindness?

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: We are but here kept like West-Indian captives,
To be devoured at some solemn meeting,
With Mirth and Jollitie; endure't who list
Let our wits work our freedom

SP.SPEAKER: Ro. Fred.
SP.L: We'l all assist.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. 1. Scen. 5.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Aurelia, Silvia, to them Sophrona, Matilda, Attendants.

SP.SPEAKER: Au.
SP.L: May not one guesse affection by a glance?

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Au.
SP.L: 'Twas but one look, and that look did it.
Those lights like Archimedes burning-glasse
Set me on Fire at that distance from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: Your meaning, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Sylvia, thou art dull,
I see, for hadst thou any sence at all,
How couldst thou choose but feel the self-same heat?

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: Explain your self, pray Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Then I will.
I'me conquer'd by my Fathers Captive.

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: Which?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Now I could chide thee for a silly Gitle:
Dost ask me which?

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: Otho's fair, Frederick smiling.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: I see my errour. Love is such a madness;
What we love, we'd have all love; and yet can't
Endure a Rival: Didst not mind him Sylvia
With the Majestick countenance? My love
Is not Effeminate, although a Womans.

L.HI: Bold Magnus!
Magnus!

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: In your cheeks I read it,
That blush betraies you; He is—

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Hush the Empress.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: Aurelia! Why were you wanting at
The sport but now?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Madam I was just comming.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: 'Twas excellent, I love to see men active.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: They're gon to visit now the Saxon Captives,
Nothing that's tending to your Fathers glory,
Must be concealed from these noble strangers.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Must Magnus make them sport?

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: Pray Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: What saith Aurelia? What's that Sylvia?

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: She's sorry, Madam, she should loose the sport.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: I thought 'twould trouble her, there's more behind,

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: But Madam, shall we never visit Rome?

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.L: We may perchance, Matilda, danger it
Now there is made this happy reconcilement.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I long to see his Holyness, methinks
I fancy most those by Religion ty'd
From lust and wedlock; am (you must concieve)
A chast Platonick Lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: What is that?
To Love, to love, and not to enjoy?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Fruition
Doth but allay those hightned flames, which are
The very life of love.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: I am but raw,
(Yet give me leave) you seem, as if Matilda
You own'd no Paradise to scorching Aetna.
Platonick loves, (like Purgatorian sires)
Doe but prepare us for a perfect blisse,
And make us worthy of a free possession.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: Aurelia, have a care my Girle, I fear
By your Romantick tongue, you may be smitten.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: If my discourse offend (my Royal Mother)
May I be ever silent rather then
Provoke your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: You do mistake the Empress.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: No matter, keep her still in Ignorance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Ours is but talk, Madam, you'l pardon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: It is Ingenious, I gladly could
Hear more on't: but I dare believe by this
They are return'd. 'Tis high time to be gon,
We must be all there: This night puts anen'd
To the Solemnity.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: We shall attend.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. II. Scen. I.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Pope, Card. Victor, other Cardinals, Attendants. The Pope ascends his Chair.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋict.
SP.L: God save Pope Gregory the Seventh! All. Long live!

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Card.
SP.L: Caesar confirmes it!

SP.SPEAKER: Pope.
SP.L: Who's that mentions Caesar?
For Policie I did complie a while,
It was but to procure the surer ground,
To give the Emperour the stronger blow.
Must Peter stoop to Caesar?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Card.
SP.L: That rests fully,
Sir, in your Holiness to remedy.

SP.SPEAKER: Po.
SP.L: My Keys already look and unlock Heaven,
And if they wont fit, I will add a ward
Wherewith they shall serve Earthly Kingdoms,
To make and unmake Princes at my pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Vict.
SP.L: Nobly Resolv'd, Sir, This will grace your See,
With the more awe and splendour.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Car.
SP.L: And restore
Rome to itsformer fame, that it shall be
Once more the worlds renown'd Metropolis.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Card.
SP.L: Henry's accus'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Pope.
SP.L: I may as well ask him
Forgivness of my sins, as to be Pope.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Card.
SP.L: He needeth pardon, Sir, or punishment,
Who is so loudly tax'd for a truce-breaker.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Card.
SP.L: The Saxons gladly would help to depose him.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Card.
SP.L: A Tyrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Vict.
SP.L: Cruel, Symoniacal,
A buisie Bodger of Church-livings, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pope.
SP.L: I hear enough: makes him uncapable,
Both of Heavens mercy, and of mans protection.
Let him be Excommunicated! lesse
Cannot be done to him, doth so transgresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: All things succeed as well as heart could wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: So, this is somewhat towards my Journey now.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: What hast thou there Jocoso?

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Nothing Sir,
But a peice for killing an good old woman,
That did so lave the house still with her nose
As she swept it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: Didst it accurately.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: To a hair, Sir, no Juggler ever playd
Legerdemaine neater, then I shook that same
Into her Hallow tooth.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: And is she dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Dead, and at heaven I hope. Her son was mad
For haste to bury her the Rushian fashion,
With Hose and Shoes, she was so troublesome
To the chymney-corner (he said) and liv'd
So unmercifully, to keep that little
She had from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: 'Twas he then gave the peice.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: It was, and to say truth, I well deserv'd it.
It did so plague me Sir, to hatch a cry,
And pray an hours nonsence by the clock.
I must not touch her, if I touch'd abook.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: I warrant 'twas one of those good women
That us'd to fetch an ill contrived sigh
At Church, in the wrong place; (not hearing well)

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: She was, all said, hugely well given Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: And so art thou, nay if thou canst Jocoso
Fanatick-like, murder with prayers and teares,
N'ere fear a livelyhood Joc. and when thy orks done,
My Fee will make me a Thanks-giving day.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: All such odd jobs I give thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: I thank you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: Come hasten, fetch our things, we must be gon.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: Now the Popes Licence without peradventure
Will be excepted from the Emperour
To gain me leave, (since they are both agreed)
To practice near his Court: My man may play
At lower stakes, and kill men for a trisle:
But where I venture Soul, Life and Estate,
It shall, believe me, cost a saucie rate.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: What! we are likely to be all to peices
Agen, Honorio, with the Emperour.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: So the newes goes, and the Popes Arrogance
Hath rais'd a civil warre amongst the Clergy.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: I am resolv'd I'le be of no religion
Till all agree.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: I must confess these failings
Shew they'r but men, but what they'd have us learn,
Is of an higher and diviner nature,
In that themselves so hardly practice it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: I cannot blame the German Bishops
To stand for their custome and prerogative.
Is there no Patriarchal seat but Rome?

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: I'me apt to think they shortly will determine
No Baptiz'd Infant, shall be call'd a Christian
Except his Name be Peter.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: Can there be
Nothing decreed without the Pope Prudentio?
Ought he, and only he, command a Council,
How, where, and when, he please?

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: This is in Truth,
Novel Encroachment, and he's like to smart for't,
Should the Prelates now joyn with th' Emperour.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: Would they were at it once.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: Will you engage?

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: There's nothing better, Boy, then Wars or Women,
To tame this Fact, and I abhor a Mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: The better Warriour.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: Those desperate Dam-hims
Who for a while may force the fare of Valour.
To stand a prick or two in vindicating
Their Ladyes naughty title to her Honour,
(To gain some Commendation, or a kindness)
Can never serve their Country worth a rush.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: Why now I like you: Gentlemen, your Hands,
You'l side with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: May we else never speed:

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: Resolve then for the Emperour.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: Agreed.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. 2. Scen. 4.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Magnus to him Otho, Frederick.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: Can her soft nature sport with th' afflicted?
I'le never think it, this were to blaspheme
Thy love Aurelia! She comes.—

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: I'le try him, Sylvia.

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: 'Tis prudence!

SP.SPEAKER: Magnus!
SP.L: I bring enlargemen and delight to be
The early messenger of welcome newes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: All thanks kind Princess: Madam you are noble:
Your Presence is a freedome.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Yours a Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: I see I was but mockt; What Scenes are these?
Such Calmes and Tempests in the self-same breath
Am I offensive?

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: You have mov'd him Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Yes, and Love-Sympathy now makes me suffer
A double torture, Magnus! Imust—

DIV3.STAGE: Drawes & gives her his Sword. aside to Silvia, gives him his Sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: Here is a Weapon, if you must dispatch me.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: He still misaprenends me Sylvia,
And how undauntedly he talks of death!
Dear Magnus! sheath, the Prison that I talkt of
Was nothing else but loves ensnarement.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: Now,
You surfet me with joy, tell't by peice-meales.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: My Fathers purpose is to set you free.

SP.SPEAKER: Magnus
SP.L: I owe it you.

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: Heaven bless these meeting flames.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Some German Princes lately proving Rebels,
Joyn with the Saxons now agen in Armes.

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: You Noble Magnus must be one of us.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Swear Loyaltie t'assist the Emperour.
Thy Valour's know.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: If I must take this oath,
I'le go and bid the Saxons, fight and help 'um;
And then return and willingly submit
To that just death my perjury deserves.
I'le prove as false to you, as to my Country.

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: Sir you'r unhandsome to your Princess.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Sylvia,
SP.L: what was't he said? He'd prove as fals
To me as to his Country, was't not so?
This is no slighting but doth argue rather
That strong and holy zeal he hath for both.
I like him better for this Resolution,
His Constancy to me and that together
Must sind a way He may be fals to neither.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. 2. Scen. 5.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Emperour, Sophrona, Matilda, Henry, Conrade, Otho. Attendants.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Were't not for these Apostatizing Germans
The Pope should feel by sad Experience,
No curse so heavy, as a Princes anger.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: These Rebels must be look'd to timely Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: I first must make my peace with Rome; or else
His Holyness will have in every Corner,
Blind zealots, that will strive by murdering me
To merit Heaven:

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: Can man be thought so stupid?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: O Madam! Ignorance leads to all mischeif.
This makes some bid good marrow to a Snaile,
Or Serpent, and Adore 'um for that day;
The Vulgar learn Rebellion still without book,
Which the Pope shuts and bids 'um read their Lessons
In his commands, which needs must be (he saith)
Alwaies Infallible.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: I see Matilda,
Thou art Ingenious, and talkst handsomly.
(ogether with the Empress) I have thought on
Employment for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.L: May we serve you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Thus I beg this Houour.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Rise, 'tis granted.
Hast courage thinkst, to face his Holyness?

SP.SPEAKER: Sop.
SP.L: Thou'rt like now to enjoy thy wish Matilda.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: You see, my Boyes, Princes are somtimes made
The Tennis-balls of Fortune, to be bandy'd
At her unconstant pleasure; now full fraught
With good success, soon after wrackt with crosses.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Sir! we are rash and inconsiderate.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: He first usurp'd the Mitre, then ask'd leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: My Children blame me Otho, that I did not
Tread upon Hildebrands submissive neck.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: You were more Noble, Sir, and Mercyful,
Who could have thought on such Hypocrisy?

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: We must not now spend all our time in talk,
Aurelia is to tender for this Journey.
Henry, and Conrade, you'r iuclin'd to travel.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: We must Sir, if it be your Royal pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Sophrona, you, and you, Matilda shall
Receive your charge anon.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: With diligence.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Otho, to you we shall commend the care
Of our affairs at Home.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: I shall be faithful.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: The Sun sometimes is darkned with Ecclipses;
And the most fixed Stats do seem to twinkle;
So must my splendour for a while be clouded:
And I! The Pilgrim-Prince, now plainly shew,
Monarchs, like Tides, do Ebb, as well as Flow.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. 3. Scen. 1,
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Aurelia, Sylvia, to them Otho, Magnus, Frederick, Rodolphus.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: The powers above must needs approve our love.
Their secret wisdome doth so prosper it.
How Melancholy would the Court be now?
Were it nor for, you know my meaning Sylvia.

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: Madam, for some divertisement, let's go
To see the Mask acted to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Agreed.
And let us go disguis'd without Attendants.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: Aurelia you are Queen we'l only act
At your command, now in your Fathers absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: You'r Gen'rous. Then my first endeavour's for
Some worthy Honour on your Countrey men.
(For your sake Otho) what shall Magnus be?

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: Thanks to our Noble Viceroy, I enjoy,
A Happiness ample enough in my
Freedome from Prison, and that Oath I hated.
But cheisly, Madam, in your government.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: This is handsome, I fear I come to late.

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: What shall be Magnus? Nothing for Rodolphus.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.L: Nor Frederick.

SP.SPEAKER: Rod.
SP.L: We'l make our selves, when once
We come i'th' field, good Otho, give us quickly
Some Martial Office or our Swords will rust.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: We'l meet to night (if it may please the Princess!)
In Council, where we all may know our charge.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: You may Command it Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: We shall attend.

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: Madam you are forgetful.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Now we'l go.
Most Noble Viceroy I must crave your leave
This afternoon to take some private repast.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: Madam, you degrade your self to ask it.

SP.SPEAKER: Au.
SP.L: I in my Fathers absence owe you dutie.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: Might I entreat your Love it were an Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: You cannot choose but have it in obedience.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: Adeiu sweet Princess.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.L: Yours

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: Farewell Sylvia.
I am resolv'd Harrie shall ne're come here,
Nor his two Sons; yet we usurpers love
To guild our Titles with some shew of ight.
There is but one lett and I'le straight remove it.
Aurelia could I once make thee my own,
I were for ever stablish'd in my Throne.

DIV3.HEAD: Act, 3. Scen. 2.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Brazutus and Jocoso, there appears an Apothecharies shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: Dull times Jocoso.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: They can never hold.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: Why Prethee.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: I Faith if they do Master,
I must like the Peruvian Cannibals,
Feast it with mans flesh, and it must be mine own.
Cur Collops here, Sir, and be merry with 'um
They'l ast as long as I, and ther's an end.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: Thou talkst too frolick, to be starv'd Jocoso.
I am already got into their fashion,
Who make their meals either with Mear, or Drink,
Not both together, our trade won't maintain it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: My takings are but small, the warrs spoil all.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Pox on it, Men are grown both hard, and holy;
I would now murder, half as cheap agen
As I did formerly, to gain some custome.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: My takings too lye all in Preservations,
Were it not for the French—

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: I have observ'd
That is the prettiest strang distemper Master,
It like a cunning Gamester hath its salf pass,
Makes at the lower parts, and hits the Nose.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: And then there's fine work that will pay us well.
T' erect a new bridg, or uphold the old one.
Here comes a Customer.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: What want you Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: Dwells here Brazutus?

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: There's my Master Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: A word or two in private.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: I shall Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: O pox! I warrant he's pepper'd by's stradling.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Are we not somewhat of the latest Sylvia?

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: Madam, they say it don't begin till four.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Let us make haste.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: What want you Ladies, pray?
Here dweleth that Renowned Don Brazutus,
That most famous Italian Physitian.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Heaven bless me, is not Otho yonder whispering?

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: The very same, what makes he here so private?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: I strang! pass on, he cannot know us Sylvia.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Those two past by, were pretty Girles I sware
If those Faces I saw were all their own.
But if they were, they are not for our purpose:
We cannot live, but by good Gentlewomen,
That undress Nature, as they dress to bed.
At night throw off their Perewigs, and their Noses.
Pull out their Teeth, and lay aside their Eies.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: I warrant Sir.

DIV3.STAGE: Jocoso orders his things in his shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: There is on other way
But this to gain Aurelia, and prepare
A free and valid passage to my suit.
Her carriage I confess seems plausible,
Yet it is nothing but Dissimulation.
Did not I see which way her amorous eye went,
And how 'twas only fix'd on him? Brazutus,
Be quick and private.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: As your own breast Sir.
I am beholding to my good old Master.
The Pope hath taught me here a blessed Lesson.
Now Mental Reservation, saves my neck,
And no way hurts my Purse, I'le out with all:
Should she love Magnus, as I am perswaded,
Aurelia's pay will excel that of Otho's.
Jocoso, Let's go in I'le give thee, Boy,
One point of Wine, to chear thee, these sad times.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: My Master hath a peice, I warrant you
He is so free, this look'd like a good chapman,
A curse upon this Primogeniture!
But a few minutes create all this trouble;
My Elder Brother carries all the Land,
And I may feed on Gallipots, and glasses.
Before I'le starve thus like a silly Elfe,
I am a Knave, if I don't Hang my self

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: The Emperour's arriv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: Fully Incens'd I guess
Against the Pope.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: We'l tame this mad usurper.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: I wish, Honorio, this Religious Rebel,
Were well chastis'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: If his Revenge be dull,
We'l whet his sword, Sir, with our active spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: First, we must understand the Princes mind,
Before we be to forward, Junio.
Only we'l give him leave to pick our meaning,
And our designes, out of our costly banquets,
And bounteous Entertainments.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: He shall read
These civil discords in the neat-wrought Sweet meats.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: I am not for these womans toyes, but if
The Wine be good, I'le carouse wholeones to Him,
And Fancy the Pope merrily tumbling down.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: This is a sharp and bitter season for 'um.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: I hear the Empress comes, and her two Sons
With a most Noble Train of handsome Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: They do not come, I hope, to fight with these.
If any thing doth make me run away,
'Twill be a womans shreicks.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: Ill, and harsh sounds
But you can't hear 'um, for the Drums and Trumpets.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: They will secure these in the Littadel.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: Poor souls! It can't but be hard servise to 'um.
They never saw such weather in their Chambers,
Which they do alwaies keep this winter quarters.
They know no Snow, but what their Wash-ball makes,
Nor Ice, but curious artificial Jellies:
Bold Boreas will disturb this Lock, that Curle,
So put them to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: Shame on their tenderness!
If I marry it shall de some Amazon,
Can fight with one hand, and give suck with t'other.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: For all your merry talking, Gentlemen,
Let's not be tardy to salute the Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: True, they deserve our early loves. No age,
Can Parrallel, this Royal Pilgrimage.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. 3. Scen. 4.

SP.SPEAKER: Pope.
SP.L: I'le be as frigid to him as the Alpes,
And the deep winter, now they travel in.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋict.
SP.L: Make him your Slave, Dread Sir, to hold your Stirrop:
Give him a good cuff if he don't do't right.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Card.
SP.L: Tread on him Sir, when you get up your Horse.

SP.SPEAKER: Pope.
SP.L: I now can make him any thing or nothing.
Having him in a treble twist; I hear,
The German Bishops back my censure, and
Their Princes wont comply, without my pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Sir The Embassy's come.

SP.SPEAKER: Pope.
SP.L: Admit them quickly,
Their Sex commands civil Respect, from all.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: Thus low we begg your Honour.

DIV3.STAGE: Sop. & Mat. kneel & kiss his Toe.

SP.SPEAKER: Pope.
SP.L: Your Business.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: Your Emperour layes his Scepter at your feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Po.
SP.L: Is't come to this? It was but lately, I
Must ask Him leave to put my Mitre on.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Sir, we appeal to you, as unto Heaven,
For Clemency, abstract from all revenge,
Or any thought on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Po.
SP.L: True. Yet sinners must
Know by our frowns wherein they have offended.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: This he doth well, Sir, and is humbled for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: If there be merit (next your Holynes)
What can be Higher then a Princes Fasting?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph,
SP.L: Three daies already, all disrob'd, and bare-foot.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: We have passed through the Island Purgatory,
In our cold progress; nor grudge we this penance,
T'arrive at Bliss, wee mean, your Holyness;
Where 'twere not Venial now, to doubt of Mercy,
For which I cannot but adore your presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Po.
SP.L: She cannot be deny'd, this Ladies converse
Becomes a Patriarch, 'tis so sublime:
Let's go conferre about this buisnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋict.
SP.L: Gladly.

SP.SPEAKER: Po.
SP.L: Madam, for your sakes I will think upon
Some termes of Pardon, (may they be accepted)
You shall anon receive um privately.

SP.SPEAKER: So. Mat.
SP.L: You Crown our wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: So.
SP.L: I'le run with this newes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Privately! Let me see! a well-thought Lady,
Must act a subtle niceness, to keep up
Her reputation, whatsoere she prove,
Were He another man, this might create
An ill conception of me: but I hope
There can be no such danger, in the Pope,

DIV3.HEAD: Act. 1. Scen. 5.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: I wonder Conrade, what th' effect will be.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Had I but had my wish, it never should
Have come to this.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: You see th' Italian Princes
Receive us Nobly, take no notice, Conrade,
At all, of th' Execration.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I have that
Within my breast, cannot abide there long:
It swells to fast.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Prethee declare what is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Will you swear secrecy, and courage then?

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: I dare to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: You shall be Emperour,
My Father dotes.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: We will divide this Honuor.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I'le ask no more, and— They come.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Pope, Victor, Cardinals, Sophrona, Matilda, Ladies, Attendants.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Let us stand here, this is the privatest.

SP.SPEAKER: Po.
SP.L: Let him b' admitted with his Royal Habet,
And order that a Banquet be prepar'd
Without delay.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: That's better then his blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Po.
SP.L: You see now Ladies, how my full desires
Do well concurre with yours in act of grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: Thanks to your Holyness we find it so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: It well becomes, Sir, your Paternal Bowels.

SP.SPEAKER: Po.
SP.L: Your Honour, (with the Emperours Pietie)
Doth stand engag'd, Matilda, to secure
The Just performance of what's offered.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: VVhat'ere is mine, Sir, may it be thought worthy,
I'le freely stake to have your will fullfil'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Po.
SP.L: I know thou 'rt Noble, if thou fancy'st Rome
Command our Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: This is exact Love-talk.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: In my heart the old fellow will prove wanton,

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: I must perforce awhile dissemble it
Thanks Holy Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: This is brave submission.

SP.SPEAKER: Po.
SP.L: You have our Absolution, and our Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Card.
SP.L: Heaven prosper, and continue these embraces!

SP.SPEAKER: Po.
SP.L: Let us refresh our selves! Fall to, Matilda.

L.HI: Musick playes and they sing within.
Your Civil jarrs
Are the worst Warrs:
But now such dangers cease:
Those Mortal Gods,
That were at odds,
Conclude an happie Peace.
It is most pleasant Harmonie,
When Crown and Mitre do agree.
We all then fear
Sad darkness near,
When Heaven's Two great Lights fight:
Whil'st Prince and Pope
Clash; there's no hope,
But the worlds fatal night.
But 'tis most pleasant Harmonie,
When Crown and Mitre do agree.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: I see the Cardinals Caps are good for somwhat.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: They hold almost a Charger full of March-paines.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Your Bounty hath oblig'd us, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Po.
SP.L: Accept it.
Now our next buisness, is to confirm all
Before the Sacred Alter.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: We attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: The face of things, methinks, seemes but untowardly,
I do not like it, Conrade, Peace can never
Sute with the nature, and complexion
Of our designes, our sport must be in Tempests.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I warrant you, rather then baulk the action,
If we find discords slow, we'l make a faction.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. 4. Scen. 1.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Brazutuss, Jocoso, as on a Stage.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Now Master ther's hopes of a Trade agen,
Things fadge so well at Rome.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: We shall anon
Have company.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: I find the Market mends.
The Clowns begin to draw their Cat-string Purses,
And call so boldly for a Pot for Joane.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: They droop'd but now, I saw, most heavily,
With their Chops leaning on their Staves, a listning,
And enquiring of every one they met,
Whether they thought this War would cause a Land Tax.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: But now they are as brisk.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: We'l try their Pockets.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: 'Tis never well but when the Glove goes, Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: The Empress will I hear honour our sport.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: I'le leap out of my skin, and in agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: I strange they tarry.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Pox on't nothing, but
Two bawling fellowes on a Ladder yonder,
Detain 'um: now they come.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Wo.
SP.L: Yonder he is.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Wo.
SP.L: Look, Jack shall see him.

SP.SPEAKER: 3. Wo.
SP.L: Poor Knave, what ailes He?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Wo.
SP.L: Alass woman he hath had an Ague this six weeks.
They say this Monster-banke knowes what's good for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.P: Gentlemen, By the help of a Divine hand, I can Cure all those Distempers, mentioned in your Paper, I need not name them. Only I am to tell you, amongst the rest, there is a Rare Jesuitical Powder, made of the skin of the Serpent the Devil possessed, when he seduced Eve. That out∣wardly applyed, will charm away any Ague, be it Tertian, Quartan, on Quotidian.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Wo.
SP.L: I am glad of that.

P.HI: I purchas'd it by my Intimacy at Rome, the Great-great-grand∣mother of all Antiquity. No one else hath it.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Master mind me

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: The price of all my things.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Master my things!

P.HI: The price of all my things, with the Directory how to use them, is Three Shillings.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Master!

P.HI: But because my time is not long with you, I shall in love give you six pence.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Master, my things!

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.P: So that you shall have all mine, and Jocoso's for three shillings in the whole,

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.P: With my Balls you may scrub up old Cloathes and Faces, and make them look like new.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Wo.
SP.L: Give me the whole parcel.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Wo.
SP.L: And me.
And me.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: My Balls help a wench to a husband quickly.
The take away all scurff, scabs and wrinckles,
redness, freckles, pimples, or any unhandsomness in the flesh.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.P: Gentlemen, if any of you be rich enough for the Gout, you must know I wrought an incomparable Cure of this lately, in Italy, on the Popes great Toe.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter a Drunken-man reeling amongst them.

SP.SPEAKER: Wo.
SP.L: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Drunk.
SP.L: What a pox do all these Fooles harkning to a couple of Knaves?

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: You make a gleak of us Gaffer.

SP.SPEAKER: Drunk.
SP.L: Are you minded to have your po. po. Pockets pickt?

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: You'r an old Rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: Friend, about your buisness.

SP.SPEAKER: Drunk.
SP.L: Kiss my Bumme.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Were I a little nearer, my foot should sweetly.

SP.SPEAKER: Wo.
SP.L: Mind him not pray, He's Drunk, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Drunk.
SP.L: Kiss my Bumme!

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: I'de drum a march on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Drunk.
SP.L: Kiss my Bu, Bu, Bumme!

SP.SPEAKER: Wo.
SP.L: Good now be quiet.

SP.SPEAKER: Bra.
SP.L: Were not this fellow drunk now, Gentlemen,
I'de make him a sad example, we come not
Here, Sirs, without leave from the Emperour.
And a full License from his Holiness.
Dispatch Jocoso.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter on the Stage an old Woman holding her Teeth.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: I have done! Here com's an object of Charity.

SP.SPEAKER: Wo.
SP.L: Pray Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Set down good woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Which Tooth is it? She hath but that.

SP.SPEAKER: Wo.
SP.L: 'Tis Ha, Hallow Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioc.
SP.L: It makes your breath stinck.
'Tis done.

SP.SPEAKER: Wo.
SP.L: I find ease.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioc.
SP.L: You have eas'd nature I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Wo.

L.HI: smells the tooth.

SP.L: What must you have.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioc.
SP.L: I have enough alreadie.

SP.SPEAKER: Wo.
SP.L: Pray Sir speak!

SP.SPEAKER: Ioc.
SP.L: Don't drop Curt'sies so, for fear your Curt'sies drop.

SP.SPEAKER: Wo.
SP.L: I'de willingly content you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioc.
SP.L: Good goodwife-house-of-Office do not follow me, so!

SP.SPEAKER: Wo.
SP.L: You must speak in my ear, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Ioc.
SP.L: Oh hell! must I come so near her. I'le have nothing Gammer!

SP.SPEAKER: Wo.
SP.L: Thank you, Sir, I am deaf.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Pox on her, she hath neither eares, nor nose.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: This goes now 'mongst my Regiment of Teeth.
Each one (like those, I read, which Cadmus sow'd,
May prove a Man of reputation.
SP.STAGE: pulls his cloath out & shews it.
SP.L: Do you not here, Sir, read a learned Artist,
As well, as in those sixteen stragling Letters
He brought to Greece? And now kind Gentlemen
Be pleas'd to walk in, (Hang me if I lye)
You shall see wonders of Activity.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. 4. Scen. 2.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Emperour, Prudentio, Honorio, Iunio. To them Henry, Conrade.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: For you we had design'd our lives and fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: This is an everlasting Infamie,
Sir, to your Royal Empire.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: He's a Lecher.
A murderer, and by lewd practises
Set on the Papacie.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Had my dull Braine,
From your first kindness apprehended you,
This nere had bin.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: In you were all our hopes,
Whom we esteem'd the Patron of all Justice,
The Alter and sole Bulwark of the Lawes

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: We valu'd not his Excommunication.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Those civil discords of the German Prinsce
Forc'd me to get this off, on such conditions,
Hell's Torment's nothing to 'um. I must stand
To the Popes Judgment; Answer mine accusers:
If guilty, quietly resign my Crowns,
In the mean time, live privately: release
My Subjects from their Loyaltie, and Oath.
And which is worst, never attempt revenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: But that good manners here constrain'd a patience
I had not heard you half out, 'twas such pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: He strives in all this but t' enslave you to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: And works his pleasure on you, thus disarm'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: We'r Idle still.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Our Swords shall cut this League.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: The Soul can be oblidg'd to nothing, but
What's free, and voluntary.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Sir, we hear
Otho Rebels, and with a num'rous Army
Bids you defiance.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Aided with Rodolphus.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: More Mischief! Your assistance Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: 'Tis ready, Sir, most willingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen. & Con.
SP.L: And ours.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: First we'l secure Home, next succeeds thy doome,
Thy doome, Proud Metropolitan of Rome.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Prepare all things in order for the Bath.
I hope by this your perfect in your Task.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Lad.
SP.L: VVe are, Dear Madam,
And are happy in 'um.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Observe your charge, I follow.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: We obey.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: 'Tis fine! the whole world is at my command.
Although I cannot bear the name of Pope,
I have the power fully, under him.
This Duke, that Cardinal, this Lord, that Abbot,
Are all my Creatures, owe me sute and servise.
All the Revenues of Rome's Mother-Church
Are scarce enough now, to maintain a Mistress.
A Lady well drest, like a Pers'an Madam
VVares sev'ral cityes on her; so must I.
The Peter Pence will find me Pins and Laces.
And —

SP.SPEAKER: Pope
SP.L: What alone, at thy private contemplations?
Let none confess thee but my self, Matilda.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Sir, you best know my secret passions.

SP.SPEAKER: Po.
SP.L: I doe, and can best pardon 'um.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: Your Cardinals.
I must retire till anon.

SP.SPEAKER: Pope.
SP.L: Your buisness.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋict.
SP.L: Sir, Th' Emperour is started from his Cov'nant
Already, and with th' Italian Nobles
Conspire your ruine.

SP.SPEAKER: Pope.
SP.L: Most unheard of falshood!
We must bestir us to be ready for 'um.
Here now I want my good old Freind Brazutus.
Can't we put confidence in Alter-vowes?
Nay; If once such Assurances be crost
As These; I'le burn the consecrated Host.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. 4. Scen. 4.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: Sirs, Now, now, let's behave our selves like men!
The stak's the Cerman Empire, and we'l share it,
Amongst us three: we'l share it equallie.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Above Emp. Hen. Con. Ho. Pru. Jun.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Will you yeild Traytors?

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: If yo'have valour for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Ye shall have mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: Dandle Fools and Children.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.L: Kingdoms are more worth then to part with so.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: Force the doores open, Sirs.
We have free entrance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: Magnus is poyson'd Otho, and his Ghost
Comes to revenge his Death.

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: Villain, I am cheated.

SP.SPEAKER: Fred.
SP.L: We are betray'd!

DIV3.STAGE: A noise within, they run, they run, they run.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: They come like lightning on us!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Hen. Con. Mag. beating Otho, Fred. Rodolp. off the Stage,

SP.SPEAKER: Otho.
SP.L: Stand to't Rodolphus.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: Now

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Junio, and Honorio, with their Swords rawn.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: Pox on't! they fled, fore I had half my sill.
Such wars as these starve a good stomackt Sword

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: They had good Heels. The Emperour's safe I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Prudentio Thanks! Thanks to you Noble Sirs!
To you we owe this conquest.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.L: To your Courage.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: And VVisdom, Sir, we must ascribe this Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: Pox! 'Twas a skirmish not worth talking of.

L.HI: Magnus!

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: The Three-Head-Traytors have their due deserts,
Rodolphus, Sir, and Frederick are slain
By the these your Noble Sons.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: VVas this your Act, My Boyes?

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: Faith fine Beginnings, Hah, Honorio.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: True.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Thanks to good Fortune, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: They're modest too.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Now Gentlemen, your swords have carv'd your way
To a most free, and well-deserved welcome,
To what 'ere Germany affords.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: All thanks.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: I long almost to see Aurelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: She'l not a little triumph at this news.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Mag. Do you conduct the Empress to us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: Sir, I obey.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Let's go.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: We all attend.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Ill luck, the old man scap'd so, were He dead
We'd never talk of Primogeniture.
But be sworn Collegues in the Empire, Conrade.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Here we were forc'd to fight, to help to save him,
We, and our hopes else had been lost for ever,
But now there is an other Warre behind,
May order all things, Harrie, to our mind.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. 4. Scen. 5.

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: Are you resolv'd to Antidate his death,
And weep his Dirge, before hand, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: I saw him murder'd, in my dream last night,
And felt the sword that did it, Sylvia!

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: These be but idle Fancies; He's alive!

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: He's run through (here I bleed) He's run through here!

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: A Messenger! what Newes!

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.L: Where's the Princess?
Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: I have but a few minutes now!

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.L: Your Royal Father hath the Victory.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: How would I fain know, what I fear to know!

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.L: Madam! The Empress with the two young Princes
Are safe returned.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Still Impertinent!

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.L: And —

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Now it comes! quick rid me out of pain.
Speak, how doth Magnus?

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.L: They are all at hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: He knows not Magnus, Madam! Now they come.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Emp. Sophrona, Magnus, Prudentio, Honorio, Junio.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: And now I see him Sylvia, or his Ghost.
Your Royal Blessings both!

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: The Heavens preserve
My Dear Aurelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: How dost, my Child?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Thanks Royal Mother: How is't Magnus?

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: Sir, you much Honour us to shew such Treasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.L: Is not she tempting, Junio?

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: In her Sex.
You know I mind no face but what's in Breeches,
And so may make a fit Companion,
For Mars, or Bachus, Fighting, boy, or Drinking.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Sirs, you shall tast our Liquor, and accept
A large Heart, with a slender Entertainment.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: Oh Sir, you all oblige us by your kindness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: 'Twas to do somwhat that can ne're be done.
'Twas to do somwhat to deserve Aurelia
And next you, to Revenge that Treacherie
I alwaies hated.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: You were ever Noble

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: Magnus is dead! don't he affright you Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Surely thou art some Sybil, Sylvia.

SP.SPEAKER: Bo.
SP.L: Lives Aurelia?
And Sylvia too?

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: Welcome sweet Princes!

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: VVhat,
You kil'd Rodolphus, and You Frederick.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: And Magnus, Otho. Now she blushes Conrade.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: 'Tis but your Fancy.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: VVe must not delay.
They will but just recruit, and then for Rome.
Come Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: VVe will follow. Sylvia!
Compose thy self for Mirth, Girle!

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: I do, Madam,
And am prepar'd to frolick, any how
You shall Command.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: The Heavens n're smil'd, till now.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. 5. Scen. 1.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter. Emperour, Prudentio, Honorio, Junio, Henry, Conrade.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Matilda! what means this? Read Gentlemen!
I am the Privy-Council of his breast
(She writes) Beware Brazutus! I live yet,
Free from all poyson, don't I? Well Matilda,
Shall not repent this kindness.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: This is he
Poyson'd Seven Popes to make use of this.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: Lives here Brazutus?

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: And his Man Jocoso.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: Beggarly Urchin! He'l kill any one,
For a Pot, Ten-groats, and the dead corps in,
To make some Mummia for th' Apothecaries.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Were they for this, thus long allow'd our Court?

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Sir, This was he, that should have poyson'd Magnus.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: To you we leave th'inspection of this buisness
Together Henry, with the government.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: I shall be Just, Sir, May you safe return!

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Be mindful of your promise Hal.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Fear nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Conrade goes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: We shall miss his Valour else.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Thanks for your Noble thoughts Prudentio.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: Would we could flie Honorio to the wars
On some swift-whinged Horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: Oh brave Junio.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen,
SP.L: Farewel! From this time shall my Raign take date,
Will Magnus second now, this pleasing Fate.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: I fear'd thee Magnus, Magnus I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: Dear Madam!
You that had got such Interest in my heart,
Methinks should know what's in't. Ther's truth written,
Not in dull Characters, but large, and lasting.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Enough!

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: Hymen cannot be wanting long.
(Madam) That blush did well become a Lady,
That must anon be chastly ravished.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Sylvia, you talk. The Empress.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: Noble Magnus!

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: Madam, was not your Journey tedious.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: 'Twas.
And now return'd we must confess, to you
We owe our selves and Kingdoms, and that ease
They do afford.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Didst hear that Sylvia?

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: This Honour justly appertains
To th' Emperour, and Your Heroick sons.
Pray do 'um Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: Courage never braggs.
Harrie how is't.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: I left 'um well, and merry.
Magnus a word or two with you, in secreet.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: What's become of Matilda, Royal Mother?
That I was thus forgetful, not to ask
Till now.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: She's grown obsequious to the Pope,
And wants for nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur,
SP.L: Oh me! I thought him
Still past a woman, by the Papian Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: She talk'd indeed at first Amorously
Of the old Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: You say right Sylvia.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Aurelia's wise, chaste, fair.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: I know all this,
And yet I'le wedd my grave, first

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Farewel then.
Avoid the Court upon my high Displeasure

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: They'r mov'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: What means all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph.
SP.L: Let us enquire.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: My Joyes are Dasht still, as they do begin
The Sun but just appear'd, and is clapt in.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. 5. Scen. 3.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: And let him flye! My pompe will be the same.
(My hopes are built upon undoubted grounds:)
Victor will be as good as Gregorie.
Command the Card'nals to recieve my pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Attend.
SP.L: We shall

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: How like you Sirs, my Dress to day?

SP.SPEAKER: Lad.
SP.L: As it becomes the Empress of the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: I know no reason for the Salique Law,
But that a woman may be fit to govern,
Or why do Poets talk of Juno Pallas.
Place pow'r and wisdom in the Female Gender?
Had not dame Nature cut us out to Rule,
She never would have giv'n us such desires,
We'l give men leave to think we think them wise,
But yet we know our strength: all States, and Persons,
(Act we discreetly) may be conquered
By our well manag'd favours.

L.HI: Without. The day's our own.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Emp. Prudentio, Hon. Jun. Souldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Secure all there.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: The buisness is effected.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: They can't be hir'd to turn agen: (Hare-like)
One Run a Post down, with his eies behind.

SP.SPEAKER: Soul.
SP.L: Make room-there, stand back

SP.SPEAKER: Hon.
SP.L: The Cardinals.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Great Sir! thus low accept my Loyalty.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp,
SP.L: Matilda, rise, we have sufficient proof of't.
Fathful, and politick were thy designes
To which we owe this bloudless victory.
How may we now requite this love?

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Our selves and service, Sirs, must be our Princes
Pure from all Mercenarie purposes.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: True. Yet Matilda we must not discourage
Our Subjects duties with Ingratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Mat.
SP.L: Then please me, Sir, in pleasuring your self,
In the Election of a Worthy Pope.
Ʋictor's demeanouors speak him such.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: We never
Sir heard the contrary.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: I do approve him.

SP.SPEAKER: Vict.
SP.L: Thanks mighty Prince!

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: God save Pope Victor the third.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Hildebrand's Name did Anagramatize
His Nature, (I HEL-BRANDD) and so he was.

SP.SPEAKER: Ho.
SP.L: He was indeed the Worlds Incendiarie.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: A Legion Rebel, (in a wicked Pope)
Must be a Complication of Traytors.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: He makes a thousand hardy-Regicides
With Pardons in their Pockets, and hopes of
Immediate access into Paradise:
With a fair promise to be Canoniz'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.L: And then Men run on in their villainies
As eagerly as e're the Pope run from us.
Pox on him! now the warrs are done, and now
We may make Mustard with our Cannon-bullets,
And stick our Swords up to hang Scare-crows on.

SP.SPEAKER: Vict.
SP.L: Will It please Caesar now to grace our Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Emp.
SP.L: Thanks to Your Holyness. Come kind Matilda.
Come Gentlemen, you shall participate.

SP.SPEAKER: Pru.
SP.L: We shall attend.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: God save Caesar and Pope Victor!

DIV3.HEAD: Act. 5. Scen. 4.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: My Revenge cannot stay the old mans pace.
I look'd for all the Empire, half, was promis'd:
And now he writes, I must submissively
Yeild to the Portion, of a Younger Brother:
And wait the leisure of the Destinies,
Or never be admitted to his Court.
Souldiers! rest confident in my Rewards!
And let them highly animate your courage!
I will not make a meal, nor close mine eyes,
Until I'me Emperour of Germany.

DIV3.L: What are you? Come, for Reconciliation?

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.L: I come to tell you, Sir, Your Fathers dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Dead!

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.L: He no sooner heard your Brothers aime,
(But He reply'd) 'twas time he was Extinguish'd,
Finding that short life, he had yet behind
Burnt like a snuff, so noysome to his issue,
His own Son Henry! And with that, he funck.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Is he quite dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.L: Dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Ther's one lett Remov'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: Brave Conrade, yeild!

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: How like a flattering Parret, the Foole talks!
Brave Conrade!

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: 'Tis your Elder Brothers Right.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Pox on't! Can High and Noble Spirits, bent
For a Kingdom, stand to tell first, and Second?
Fight, Fight! I'le quickly make a younger Brother
Of thee Magnus.

DIV3.STAGE: They all fight, Conrad's Souldiers are beaten off the Stage, Magnus kills Conrade.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: There was no way but death.

SP.SPEAKER: Soul.
SP.L: We have the Conquest, Sir, they are quite Routed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: Conveigh this Corps to Solemn Funeral,
We cannot but Lament Bold Conrade's Fall.

DIV3.HEAD: Act. 5. Scen. 5.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Officers with Brazutus, Jocoso, and a mixt Company

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Off.
SP.L: Along, Along!

SP.SPEAKER: Braz.
SP.L: What are we apprehended for?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Off.
SP.L: The Emperour will tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Off.
SP.L: Come along.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: So I can, you Hunger-starved-Hound
Without your Haleing.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Wo.
SP.L: They are very cheats.

SP.SPEAKER: 3. Wo.
SP.L: They mump'd poor Besse.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Wo.
SP.L: Their things w'ant worth a Farthing.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: Hang 'um, hang 'um they do but gull the Country.

SP.SPEAKER: Braz.
SP.L: This daies work shall cost you dear.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Off.
SP.L: 'Tmay cost your life.

SP.SPEAKER: Braz.
SP.L: I had a License from His Royal Father:
Nor will the Princess thank you for this rudeness.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Off.
SP.L: W'have order never fear't for what we do.

SP.SPEAKER: Braz.
SP.L: Y'have spoyl'd a Chymistrie cost (God kowes what)

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Y'have brain'd the Gallipots, ye Rogues! the stuff
Runs out, shall cost you sauce, I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Off.
SP.L: Come, come, a Halter will soon spoil your rayling.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: You may deserve it first.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: Hang'um quick, Hang'um

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.L: Peace, The Emperour.

SP.SPEAKER: Wo.
SP.L: Take heed you be'nt in the old womans pickle,
By and by, Sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Go you Bob-tail'd Whores.

SP.SPEAKER: Wo.
SP.L: You whore-son Arse-gut!

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.L: Peace the Emperour

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Magnus, I am oblig'd. —

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.L: Sir, here's the Pris'ner.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Brazutus! you endeavoured to poyson
Our Royal Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Braz.
SP.L: Sir, I'me ignorant.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: If you conceal't I shall the rather think it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: Perhaps, Matilda might not send the Letter,
Pope Gregorie intended for this purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Confess all or else you dye.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: I n'ere, Sir, murder'd any in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Braz.
SP.L: The old Woman. (I hate lying)

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: I did but faign that, Sir, to get his service.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: How now Brazutus?

SP.SPEAKER: Braz.
SP.L: Sir, this is but malice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: If clear in this yet they may both be faulty.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Declare Brazutus what you're committed,
And on a Princes word, you shall have mercy.
(For your sake Magnus and Aurelia's.)

SP.SPEAKER: Braz.
SP.L: If I am guilty, Sir, of this I'me tax'd of,
May I for ever be debarr'd your bounty.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Speak all you know, or ever did, Jocoso.
If you'r found in a tittle fals, you dye.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: I never murder'd any but my Mother,
Which Nature had almost done to my Hand.
Besides it was my Elder Brothers doings.
She liv'd so long He thought she was Immortal.
His mind was once, to try whether she'd drown:
But I was forc'd at last to doe her work
For a mean Fee; I might have starv'd else, Sir.
Your mercy, Sir, your mercy!

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Horrid Villain!

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: But that your word joyn'd with the Jubilee
Of your first Raign, pleads somewhat, Sir, for life,
There could be no escaping of the Gallows:
However pray think on some punishment
That may be next to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Friends, hear your sentence.
Brazutus! You Equivocated with us,
More then Jocoso in your slie confession.
(Who poyson'd a Septinary of Popes!
Both shall live in perpetual Prisonment:
look to them Officers, and see that daylie
A hard allowance, mind them of their faults.

SP.SPEAKER: Off.
SP.L: Sir We obey.
'Tis well yee scape so

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Off.
SP.L: Come my Friend, Jocoso.

SP.SPEAKER: Joc.
SP.L: Pox on your Frendship, would we n'ere had met!
How Intimate I must be now with Hell!

SP.SPEAKER: Braz.
SP.L: The best on't is, old age, ill-us'd
Can't suffer me, to be Tenant to a Prison long!

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Magnus! whate're the German Empire now
Rightly descended to me, will afford,
Command it freely.

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: May Heaven prosper Caesar!

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Look yonder Sylvia.

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: I like this well.

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: Must Magnus now be Banish'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: Sweet Aurelia!
I can as soon be banish'd from my self.
(Give me leave Sister) You will have a man,
Made up of Love, of Justice, and of Honour.
I might have call'd these Virtues into question,
Had he yeilded to me in hindering
My Fathers Return, to his Empire: which
None but the Fates prevented.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.L: Heaven Bless Caesar!

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: Next we must Palliate Sophrona's greif.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: That must be Magnus in your Nuptials.
Great Duke of Saxony! accept your Dutchess,
Accept of your Aurelia!

SP.SPEAKER: Aur.
SP.L: I flye to Him.

SP.SPEAKER: Syl.
SP.L: Blest pair, may yours no more prove April-joyes!

SP.SPEAKER: Mag.
SP.L: We prize things most got through a world of Crosses.

SP.SPEAKER: Hen.
SP.L: When those are quite blown over: and now may
You (like the City Alexandria)
Enjoy a constant Sun-shine ev'ry day!

LG.L: I am to tell you (Gentlemen!) The Play
Caesar's sad Tragoedie, you saw to day.
Should any Momus crie, it can't be true.
A man Religious, and a Rebel, too.

L.HI: Carp at the Title first, and next the Plot,
And then the Sence, the Language, and what not!
Condemn this Poyson, this Lust, and that Treason,

LG.L: And sware, our Pilgrim-Prince can't stand to reason;

L.HI: (But as a Vulgar Errour straight must be

LG.L: Our Poet doth confess, and 'tis His glory,

L.HI: He plaid the Theif, he saith, and stole the story
From men of Trust, who write, the thing was so,
Acted about Six Hundred years agoe.
But yet all this won't do He understands,
Nothing will pass for good, without your Hands.
For which great favour, (she who did express
Her self so handsome to his Holiness.)
If such a freindly Girle don't get a clap.
